ground_truth: The curricle continues on its way, with Mr. Collins perched on the back. Now, he's standing in the parlor as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary enter. The three girls sit down. Jane and Lizzie rise from their seats. Lizzie and Jane have sat back down again, and Mr. Collins regards the three girls with condescension. The three sisters are now standing, watching him coldly. Having backed out of the parlor, he makes his way over to the curricle outside. With a sympathetic shake of the head, he climbs up into the carriage. Lizzie and Jane have come out to see him off. They wave him off. As soon as the coast is clear, Kitty peers out from behind a wall. She bustles over to the house. Lydia is sitting, looking out of a lead-paned window, humming happily to herself. She glances over at Wickham. Wickham smiles. At Longbourn, Jane runs up the stairs. She bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room. Jane wafts the vial under her mother's nose. Mr. Bennet arrives home in the pouring rain. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him. He steps inside, takes off his top hat and black cloak, and heads into his study, closing the door behind him. Jane and Lizzie are watching him with some concern. The two sisters exchange worried glances. Mr. Darcy is wandering through a cobbled street, bustling with people and horses. He makes his way down the crowded street, looking slightly lost. When he reaches a corner, a young beggar girl stops him to ask for money. As he searches his pockets for coins, he asks her for directions. She indicates the road he should take. Finally, he finds the house he's looking for and bangs on the door. As the door opens, a woman looks shocked to see Darcy. Her housekeeper quickly tries to shut him out. The Bennet sisters are still sitting in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just going to pour the tea when Mr. Bennet comes in. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat. Kitty is sobbing. Seeing Kitty's distress, Mr. Bennet's face falls, and he leaves the room. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back out, searching the darkened streets, clutching a piece of paper in his hand. He gazes up at a house. Lydia, meanwhile, is getting more and more bored by the minute. She gets up off the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham's drinking wine. A young man is galloping along on horseback in the bright sunshine. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn, and seeing the messenger arriving, quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag, dismounts, and gives it to her in exchange for a few coins.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The carriage continues on its route, with Mr. Collins perched on the rear. Now, he's standing in the living room as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary enter. The three young women sit down. Jane and Lizzie rise from their places. Lizzie and Jane have resumed their seats, and Mr. Collins views the three young women with patronization. The three sisters are now standing, observing him coldly. Having retreated out of the living room, he makes his way over to the carriage outside. With a compassionate shake of the head, he climbs up into the vehicle. Lizzie and Jane have emerged to see him off. They wave him off. As soon as the coast is clear, Kitty peers out from behind a barrier. She bustles over to the dwelling. Lydia is sitting, looking out of a lead-paned window, humming cheerfully to herself. She glances over at Wickham. Wickham grins. At Longbourn, Jane dashes up the stairs. She bursts into Mrs. Bennet's chamber. Jane wafts the vial under her mother's nose. Mr. Bennet arrives home in the drenching rain. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him. He steps inside, removes his top hat and dark cloak, and heads into his study, closing the door behind him. Jane and Lizzie are observing him with some worry. The two sisters exchange anxious glances. Mr. Darcy is wandering through a cobbled street, bustling with people and horses. He makes his way down the crowded street, looking slightly disoriented. When he reaches a corner, a young beggar girl halts him to request money. As he searches his pockets for coins, he asks her for directions. She indicates the path he should take. Finally, he finds the residence he's seeking and bangs on the door. As the door opens, a woman appears shocked to see Darcy. Her housekeeper quickly attempts to shut him out. The Bennet sisters are still sitting in the living room. Jane puts down her book and is just going to pour the tea when Mr. Bennet enters. All four young women look at him expectantly as he takes a seat. Kitty is weeping. Seeing Kitty's distress, Mr. Bennet's expression falls, and he exits the room. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back out, searching the shadowed streets, clutching a sheet of paper in his hand. He gazes up at a residence. Lydia, meanwhile, is becoming more and more bored by the minute. She rises from the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham's drinking wine. A young man is galloping along on horseback in the brilliant sunshine. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn, and seeing the courier arriving, quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag, dismounts, and gives it to her in exchange for a few coins.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The curricle continues, with Mr. Collins on the back. He enters the parlor as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary sit. Jane and Lizzie rise, then sit again. Mr. Collins regards them condescendingly. The sisters stand, watching him coldly as he exits to the curricle. Sympathetically shaking his head, he climbs in. Lizzie and Jane see him off. When the coast is clear, Kitty peers out and rushes to the house. Lydia sits by a lead-paned window, happily humming, glancing at Wickham, who smiles. At Longbourn, Jane bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room, wafting a vial under her nose. Mr. Bennet returns home in heavy rain. Jane and Lizzie await him. He enters, removes his hat and cloak, and goes to his study. Jane and Lizzie exchange worried glances. Mr. Darcy walks through a bustling cobbled street, slightly lost. A beggar asks him for money, and he asks for directions. He finds the house and knocks. A woman looks shocked as her housekeeper quickly tries to shut him out. Back at the parlor, Jane puts down her book to pour tea when Mr. Bennet enters. The girls look expectantly as he sits. Kitty sobs, and Mr. Bennet's face falls as he leaves the room. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy searches dark streets, clutching paper, gazing at a house. Lydia grows bored and moves to the window. Wickham drinks wine. A young man gallops on horseback in sunshine. The housekeeper at Longbourn sees a messenger and hurries to meet him. He dismounts, delivers a letter, and receives coins.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Mr. Collins rides in the curricle, then stands in the parlor as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary enter and sit. Jane and Lizzie rise, then sit again, while Mr. Collins regards them condescendingly. As they stand coldly watching, he exits to the curricle, and Lizzie and Jane see him off. Once he's gone, Kitty appears and hurries to the house as Lydia hums by the window, gazing at smiling Wickham. At Longbourn, Jane rushes to Mrs. Bennet's room, waving a vial under her nose when Mr. Bennet arrives home in the rain. He enters, removes his top hat and cloak, and heads to his study, with Jane and Lizzie exchanging worried looks. Mr. Darcy wanders through busy streets, stopping to give a beggar girl coins and ask for directions. He finds a house, knocks, and a shocked woman tries to shut him out. The Bennet sisters in the parlor expectantly watch as Mr. Bennet enters. Seeing Kitty's distress, he leaves. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy searches dark streets, paper in hand, while Lydia grows bored, moving to the window as Wickham drinks. A young man gallops in sunshine; the Longbourn housekeeper sees him, rushes to meet him, and exchanges coins for a letter.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The curricle continues on its way, with Mr. Collins comfortably perched on the back of the moving carriage. Now, he is found standing in the elegant parlor as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary gracefully make their entrance. The three girls proceed to sit down promptly. However, Jane and Lizzie quickly rise from their seats, only to find themselves sitting back down again. Mr. Collins regards the three young ladies with an air of condescension. The three sisters are now standing, observing him with a cold and detached demeanor. Having awkwardly backed out of the parlor, he makes his way over to the waiting curricle outside. With a sympathetic shake of his head, he climbs up into the carriage. Lizzie and Jane have come out to bid him farewell. They wave him off with polite gestures. As soon as the coast is clear, Kitty emerges cautiously from behind a wall. She bustles over to the house with a sense of urgency. Lydia is sitting comfortably, gazing out of a charming lead-paned window, humming to herself in a carefree manner. She glances over at Wickham, who responds with a warm smile. At Longbourn, Jane hurries up the stairs energetically. She bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room with a sense of purpose, waving the vial under her mother's nose. Mr. Bennet arrives home amidst the pouring rain. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him with anticipation. He steps inside, removes his top hat and black cloak, and heads directly into his study, closing the door firmly behind him. Jane and Lizzie watch him with some growing concern. The two sisters exchange worried glances, their expressions betraying their unease. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is wandering through a bustling cobbled street, filled with both people and horses. He makes his way down the crowded street, appearing slightly lost amidst the chaos. When he reaches a corner, a young beggar girl approaches him to ask for money. As he searches his pockets for coins, he also requests directions from her. She kindly indicates the road he should take. Finally, he locates the house he has been searching for and bangs determinedly on the door. As the door opens, a woman appears shocked to see Darcy standing there. Her housekeeper quickly attempts to shut him out. Back in the Bennet household, the sisters are still gathered in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just about to pour the tea when Mr. Bennet enters the room. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat among them. Kitty is sobbing inconsolably. Seeing Kitty's distress, Mr. Bennet's face falls, and he quietly leaves the room. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back out, navigating through the darkened streets, clutching a piece of paper in his hand. He gazes intently up at a particular house. In the meantime, Lydia is growing more and more bored with each passing minute. She gets up from the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham is enjoying a glass of wine leisurely. A young man is galloping spiritedly along on horseback in the bright sunshine. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn, and upon seeing the messenger arriving, she quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag, dismounts efficiently, and hands it to her in exchange for a few shiny coins.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The curricle continues steadily on its journey, with Mr. Collins comfortably perched upon the back of the moving carriage as it makes its way forward. Now, the scene shifts, and we find him standing rather awkwardly in the elegant and finely appointed parlor, where Jane, Lizzie, and Mary make their graceful entrance with poise. The three girls proceed to sit down without delay, only for Jane and Lizzie to unexpectedly rise from their seats, only to find themselves promptly sitting back down once more. Mr. Collins regards the three young ladies with an air of unmistakable condescension. The three sisters are now standing, observing him with a cold and detached demeanor, their expressions impassive. Having awkwardly backed out of the parlor, he makes his way over to the waiting curricle outside. With a sympathetic shake of his head, expressing some unspoken regret or understanding, he climbs up into the carriage. Lizzie and Jane come out to bid him farewell, offering polite gestures as they wave him off. As soon as the coast is clear, Kitty emerges cautiously from behind a nearby wall. She bustles over to the house with an evident sense of urgency. Inside, Lydia is sitting comfortably, gazing dreamily out of a charming lead-paned window, humming to herself in a carefree and lighthearted manner. She glances over at Wickham, who responds to her with a warm and reassuring smile. At Longbourn, Jane hurries up the stairs energetically. She bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room with a determined sense of purpose, waving the vial under her mother's nose. Mr. Bennet arrives home amidst the relentless pouring rain. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him with visible anticipation. He steps inside, removes his top hat and black cloak, and heads directly into his study, closing the door firmly behind him. Jane and Lizzie watch him with growing concern and unease. The two sisters exchange worried glances, their expressions betraying their shared anxiety. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is wandering through a bustling cobbled street, brimming with both people and horses. He makes his way down the crowded street, appearing slightly lost amidst the chaos and activity. When he reaches a corner, a young beggar girl approaches him to ask for money. As he searches his pockets for coins, he also takes the opportunity to request directions from her. She kindly and helpfully indicates the road he should take. Finally, he locates the house he has been searching for and bangs determinedly on the door with purpose. As the door opens, a woman appears visibly shocked to see Darcy standing there. Her housekeeper quickly attempts to shut him out. Back in the Bennet household, the sisters are still gathered in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just about to pour the tea when Mr. Bennet enters the room. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat among them. Kitty is sobbing inconsolably. Seeing Kitty's distress, Mr. Bennet's face falls in quiet dismay, and he quietly leaves the room. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back out, navigating through the darkened streets, clutching a piece of paper in his hand. He gazes intently up at a particular house. Meanwhile, Lydia is growing more and more bored with each passing minute. She gets up from the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham is enjoying a glass of wine leisurely. A young man is galloping spiritedly along on horseback in the bright sunshine. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn, and upon seeing the messenger arriving, she quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag, dismounts efficiently, and hands it to her in exchange for a few shiny coins.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The curricle continues smoothly along the road with Mr. Collins carefully perched on the back, maintaining his balance as the landscape rolls by. Once it halts, he dismounts and enters the parlor, where he positions himself with a somewhat formal stance as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary step into the room. The three girls move together toward the seating area and each takes a seat, sinking into the cushions. Jane and Lizzie soon rise from their chairs, only to sit back down again, as if indecisive or unsure of the moment, and Mr. Collins regards them with a condescending air, his expression reflecting a sense of superiority. The sisters, feeling the weight of his gaze, stand up again, their demeanor shifting to cold watchfulness as they observe him. Mr. Collins, seemingly aware of the tension, carefully backs out of the parlor, maneuvering his way between the furniture, and heads toward the curricle parked outside. He reaches it with a slight, sympathetic shake of his head, signaling some unspoken understanding, and climbs up into the carriage, finding his place once more. Lizzie and Jane have stepped outside to see him off, waving their farewells as the carriage begins to pull away from the house. Once the curricle is out of sight, Kitty, who has been hiding discreetly behind a wall, peeks out, ensuring the coast is clear. She quickly bustles over to the house with a sense of urgency and purpose. Inside, Lydia sits gazing out through the lead-paned window, her eyes taking in the view as she hums a cheerful tune to herself. Her attention shifts momentarily to Wickham, who is nearby, and as their eyes meet, Wickham offers her a smile, adding a lighter note to the atmosphere. Meanwhile, at Longbourn, Jane hurries up the stairs, her movements brisk and purposeful, and bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room, her entrance filled with urgency. She gently wafts a vial under her mother’s nose, providing her with some form of relief or comfort. Outside, Mr. Bennet arrives home under a heavy downpour, rain cascading off his form as he approaches the door. Jane and Lizzie wait anxiously inside for his arrival, looking out expectantly. As he steps inside, he removes his top hat and shakes off his black cloak, then heads directly into his study, where he closes the door, momentarily shutting himself away. Jane and Lizzie watch this sequence unfold with concern etched on their faces, exchanging worried glances as they interpret the mood. Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy wanders amid a bustling cobbled street, surrounded by the clamor of people and horses, his demeanor slightly lost amid the chaotic scene. He weaves his way down the crowded street, trying to find his bearings, and is eventually stopped by a young beggar girl who asks him for money. While he fumbles through his pockets searching for coins, he inquires about directions, listening intently as she indicates the path he should take. Armed with this new information, he presses on until he locates the house he has been searching for and decisively bangs on the door. When the door swings open, a woman stands shocked at the sight of him, her expression quickly followed by the housekeeper’s urgent attempt to shut him out, closing off whatever interaction might have ensued. Back at the parlor, the Bennet sisters sit together once more, exchanging looks of shared understanding as Jane gently places her book aside and prepares to pour the tea, her movements calm and practiced when Mr. Bennet enters the room. The four girls turn their eyes towards him, anticipation hanging in the air as they wait for him to speak or act. Kitty, overcome with emotion, sobs quietly, her distress visibly etched on her face. Noticing Kitty’s tears, Mr. Bennet’s expression shifts to one of empathy and concern as his face falls, prompting him to leave the room, carrying the burden of her sadness with him. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back outside, traversing the dim and darkened streets once more, clutching a piece of paper that serves as his guide. His eyes travel upwards as he gazes at a particular house, contemplating his next move. Inside, Lydia, restless with boredom, rises from her place on the bed and wanders over to the window, seeking some distraction or entertainment as Wickham sips wine nearby, lost in his own thoughts. In a different setting, a young man gallops energetically along the bright sunshine-filled landscape on horseback, the scene vibrant with life and motion. Meanwhile, at Longbourn, the housekeeper peers vigilantly out of the window, and upon seeing the approaching messenger, she quickly hurries to meet him before he can even dismount. He retrieves a letter from his saddlebag, passing it to her in exchange for a few coins, fulfilling his duty with practiced efficiency.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The curricle continues its journey with Mr. Collins perched on the back. Inside the parlor, Mr. Collins stands as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary enter and sit. Jane and Lizzie briefly stand, then sit again, prompting Mr. Collins to regard them condescendingly. As the sisters stand coldly watching him, he exits the parlor and heads outside to the curricle. Lizzie and Jane come out to see him off, waving as he departs. Once he's gone, Kitty emerges from behind a wall and hurries to the house, while Lydia hums happily, glancing at Wickham, who smiles back. At Longbourn, Jane rushes to Mrs. Bennet's room and revives her with a vial. Mr. Bennet arrives home drenched from the rain, greeted by Jane and Lizzie's concerned glances. He removes his hat and cloak, entering his study and closing the door. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy navigates a bustling cobbled street, slightly lost, until a beggar girl directs him. Finding the house he seeks, he knocks, surprising the woman who answers, while her housekeeper attempts to shut him out. Back in the parlor, Jane sets her book aside to pour tea as Mr. Bennet enters, met by the sisters' expectant looks. Upset by Kitty's sobbing, his face falls as he exits. Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy searches dark streets with a paper in hand, gazing at a house. Meanwhile, Lydia, growing bored, moves to the window, while Wickham drinks wine. A young man gallops toward Longbourn in the sunshine, and the housekeeper quickly meets him. He dismounts, hands her a letter in exchange for coins, and departs.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The curricle, a light, open two-wheeled carriage popular in the 18th and early 19th centuries, continues on its way, with Mr. Collins perched on the back. Now, he's standing in the parlor, a room often used for receiving guests in English country homes, as Jane, Lizzie, and Mary enter. The three girls sit down. Jane and Lizzie rise from their seats. Lizzie and Jane have sat back down again, and Mr. Collins, known for his sycophantic behavior and lack of social grace, regards the three girls with condescension. The three sisters are now standing, watching him coldly. Having backed out of the parlor, he makes his way over to the curricle outside. With a sympathetic shake of the head, he climbs up into the carriage. Lizzie and Jane have come out to see him off, waving from the gravel driveway typical of estates like Longbourn. They wave him off. As soon as the coast is clear, Kitty, often the most curious of the sisters, peers out from behind a wall. She bustles over to the house. Lydia is sitting, looking out of a lead-paned window, typical in Georgian architecture, humming happily to herself. She glances over at Wickham, whose charm and handsome appearance often mask his unscrupulous nature. Wickham smiles. At Longbourn, the Bennet family home, Jane runs up the creaking wooden stairs. She bursts into Mrs. Bennet's room, where their mother often recuperates from her frequent nerves. Jane wafts the vial of smelling salts, a common remedy for faintness, under her mother's nose. Mr. Bennet arrives home in the pouring rain, his return marked by the clatter of horse hooves on rainy cobblestones. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him. He steps inside, takes off his top hat and black cloak, and heads into his study, a sanctuary filled with books and papers, closing the door behind him. Jane and Lizzie are watching him with some concern. The two sisters exchange worried glances. Mr. Darcy is wandering through a cobbled street, bustling with people and horses, reflecting the vibrant commerce of the town. He makes his way down the crowded street, looking slightly lost. When he reaches a corner, a young beggar girl, a common sight in the 19th-century urban landscape, stops him to ask for money. As he searches his pockets for coins, he asks her for directions. She indicates the road he should take. Finally, he finds the house he's looking for and bangs on the door. As the door opens, a woman looks shocked to see Darcy, whose social standing often precedes him. Her housekeeper quickly tries to shut him out, fearing any disruption to their daily routine. The Bennet sisters are still sitting in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just going to pour the tea, a staple of English social life, when Mr. Bennet comes in. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat. Kitty is sobbing. Seeing Kitty's distress, Mr. Bennet's face falls, and he leaves the room, likely heading to his study to ponder the family's challenges. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is back out, searching the darkened streets, clutching a piece of paper in his hand, perhaps a letter of great importance. He gazes up at a house. Lydia, meanwhile, is getting more and more bored by the minute, her restlessness a familiar trait. She gets up off the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham's drinking wine, a pastime that sometimes loosens his already lax morals. A young man is galloping along on horseback in the bright sunshine, his urgency evident in the speed of his ride. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn, and seeing the messenger arriving, quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag, dismounts, and gives it to her in exchange for a few coins, knowing that such deliveries are vital to maintaining social connections in their world.

Finally he finds the house he is looking for and bangs on the door. As the door opens a woman looks shocked to see Darcy. Her housekeeper quickly tries to shut him out. The Bennet sisters are still sitting in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just going to pour the tea when Mr Bennet comes in. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat. Kitty is sobbing. Seeing Kitty's distress Mr Bennet's face falls and he leaves the room. Meanwhile Mr Darcy is back out searching the darkened streets clutching a piece of paper in his hand. He gazes up at a house. Lydia meanwhile is getting more and more bored by the minute. She gets up off the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham's drinking wine. A young man is galloping along on horseback in the bright sunshine. The housekeeper peers out of the window at Longbourn and seeing the messenger arriving quickly hurries out to meet him. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag dismounts and gives it to her in exchange for a few coins.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The curricle continues on its way with Mr Collins perched on the back. Now he is standing in the parlor as Jane Lizzie and Mary enter. The three girls sit down. Jane and Lizzie rise from their seats. Lizzie and Jane have sat back down again and Mr Collins regards the three girls with condescension. The three sisters are now standing watching him coldly. Having backed out of the parlor he makes his way over to the curricle outside. With a sympathetic shake of the head he climbs up into the carriage. Lizzie and Jane have come out to see him off. They wave him off. As soon as the coast is clear Kitty peers out from behind a wall. She bustles over to the house. Lydia is sitting looking out of a leadpaned window humming happily to herself. She glances over at Wickham. Wickham smiles. At Longbourn Jane runs up the stairs. She bursts into Mrs Bennet's room. Jane wafts the vial under her mother's nose. Mr Bennet arrives home in the pouring rain. Jane and Lizzie are waiting for him. He steps inside takes off his top hat and black cloak and heads into his study closing the door behind him. Jane and Lizzie are watching him with some concern. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. The two sisters exchange worried glances. Mr Darcy is wandering through a cobbled street bustling with people and horses. He makes his way down the crowded street looking slightly lost. When he reaches a corner a young beggar girl stops him to ask for money. As he searches his pockets for coins he asks her for directions. She indicates the road he should take. Finally he finds the house he is looking for and bangs on the door. As the door opens a woman looks shocked to see Darcy. Her housekeeper quickly tries to shut him out. The Bennet sisters are still sitting in the parlor. Jane puts down her book and is just going to pour the tea when Mr Bennet comes in. All four girls look at him expectantly as he takes a seat. He gazes up at a house. Lydia meanwhile is getting more and more bored by the minute. She gets up off the bed and wanders over to the window. Wickham's drinking wine. He pulls a letter out of his saddlebag dismounts and gives it to her in exchange for a few coins.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The canoe drifts along its path, with Mr. Zeke lounging on the roof. Now, he's standing in the kitchen as Mia, Ella, and Lily wander in. The trio of cats lie down. Mia and Ella jump from their couches. Ella and Mia have sprawled back once more, and Mr. Zeke observes the trio of cats with arrogance. The three kittens are now perching, observing him coolly. Having slipped out of the kitchen, he strolls over to the canoe outside. With a regretful wag of the finger, he climbs up into the gondola. Ella and Mia have come out to send him off. They wave him away. As soon as the path is empty, Clara peeks out from behind a tree. She scampers over to the barn. Alyssa is reclining, gazing out of a stained-glass door, singing cheerfully to herself. She peeks over at Edwin. Edwin winks. At Meadowfield, Mia climbs up the ladder. She storms into Mrs. Harrison's closet. Mia wafts the aroma under her aunt's chin. Mr. Harrison arrives home in the blazing sunlight. Mia and Ella are waiting for him. He steps inside, takes off his beanie and red scarf, and heads into his library, closing the flap behind him. Mia and Ella are observing him with some suspicion. The two kittens trade anxious smirks. Mr. Wilson is strolling through a pebbled marketplace, bustling with traders and carriages. He makes his way down the busy lane, appearing slightly unsure. When he reaches a junction, a young flower merchant stops him to offer blossoms. As he searches his pockets for petals, he asks her for directions. She suggests the path he should follow. At last, he finds the shack he's seeking and hammers on the door. As the entrance opens, a man looks startled to see Wilson. Her butler hurriedly tries to bar him out. The Harrison kittens are still lounging in the garden. Mia sets down her scroll and is just about to brew the coffee when Mr. Harrison strolls in. All four kittens peer at him eagerly as he settles down. Clara is wailing. Noticing Clara's anguish, Mr. Harrison's expression changes, and he exits the space. Meanwhile, Mr. Wilson is back out, navigating the dimly lit alleys, gripping a scrap of cloth in his fist. He stares up at a mansion. Alyssa, meanwhile, is growing more and more restless by the second. She leaps off the perch and gazes over to the terrace. Edwin's sipping ale. A young woman is bounding along on a tandem bike in the radiant moonlight. The butler peeks out of the terrace at Meadowfield, and noticing the courier departing, rapidly dashes out to greet her. She pulls a package out of her basket, dismounts, and hands it to him in exchange for a handful of candy.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mr. Collins stands in the parlor with Jane, Lizzie, and Mary, showing condescension toward the sisters. After leaving the parlor, he departs in a curricle, waved off by Jane and Lizzie. Once the coast is clear, Kitty approaches the house, while Lydia hums by a window, glancing at Wickham. At Longbourn, Jane urgently enters Mrs. Bennet's room. Mr. Bennet arrives home in the rain to find Jane and Lizzie concerned. He retreats to his study, leaving them worried. Mr. Darcy, wandering through busy streets, assists a beggar in exchange for directions and finally finds his destination. Inside, a woman is shocked to see him, and the housekeeper attempts to shut him out. The Bennet sisters sit in the parlor, anticipating Mr. Bennet’s arrival, who leaves upon seeing Kitty's distress. Meanwhile, Darcy searches the dark streets, holding a piece of paper. Lydia grows bored, watching Wickham drink wine. A young man on horseback delivers a letter to Longbourn's housekeeper, who exchanges coins for it.
